headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it's been a few years now since I think your last big addition with respect to route capacity. How are you guys thinking about route capacity going forward? Is it going to be added on really on an as-needed basis? Or potentially we could be seeing a br
componenttext: So it's been a few years now since I think your last big addition with respect to route capacity. How are you guys thinking about route capacity going forward? Is it going to be added on really on an as-needed basis? Or potentially we could be seeing a broad-based addition like we had a few years ago?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Generally, Joe, we want to continue to add routes throughout each year, and we have continued to do that -- I -- so I wouldn't expect it would have a big influx of routes anytime soon. But a little bit depends on the nature of the economy and what we are
componenttext: Generally, Joe, we want to continue to add routes throughout each year, and we have continued to do that -- I -- so I wouldn't expect it would have a big influx of routes anytime soon. But a little bit depends on the nature of the economy and what we are -- what we're seeing with our customers. But I would say, I wouldn't expect to have an influx of new routes in the rental business. In the first aid business, we have continued to add routes. We've -- we have in that business, our SSRIs really do drive a lot of growth, and we want to make sure that they have the capacity, the time to spend selling. And so what we're fairly aggressive in adding routes to that business. But I will tell you with the the acquisition, there is a lot of integration to be doing, and we're going to have to take that quarter by quarter.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just as a follow-up on a macro point you made earlier, I mean I think we have a pretty good sense on what's going on in oil and gas and mining. But I'm curious  if you're maybe seeing a bifurcation between industrial-oriented customers outs
componenttext: And then maybe just as a follow-up on a macro point you made earlier, I mean I think we have a pretty good sense on what's going on in oil and gas and mining. But I'm curious  if you're maybe seeing a bifurcation between industrial-oriented customers outside of oil and gas and mining versus maybe what you're seeing from consumer-driven businesses? And if you are seeing any sort of a change, how might that impact you?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say that we're seeing a marketable change from the other customers, but the environment's been pretty good. I mean, they are -- when we can show them value, they will take additional products and services that do add that value. But I wouldn't
componenttext: I wouldn't say that we're seeing a marketable change from the other customers, but the environment's been pretty good. I mean, they are -- when we can show them value, they will take additional products and services that do add that value. But I wouldn't say that we've seen a marketable change to that, but certainly, a different operating environment than our oil, gas and mining customers.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then one last one for me. Paul, what is the margin tailwind in the uniform rental business just from the extra day?
componenttext: And then one last one for me. Paul, what is the margin tailwind in the uniform rental business just from the extra day?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe, typically that extra day in the quarter gives us about 40 to 50 basis point improvement.
componenttext: Joe, typically that extra day in the quarter gives us about 40 to 50 basis point improvement.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if I wee to strip out the 40 to 50 basis points, and I think you said there was 90 basis points of tailwind from energy in the uniform rental business, net-net, we're looking at a gross margin that's down in the uniform rental business. Can you m
componenttext: Okay. So if I wee to strip out the 40 to 50 basis points, and I think you said there was 90 basis points of tailwind from energy in the uniform rental business, net-net, we're looking at a gross margin that's down in the uniform rental business. Can you maybe put some color around why it would have been down x of those items?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, we had a 70 basis, in the rental business, we had a 70 basis points tailwind from energy, roughly a 40 -- when we say 40 to 50 basis points of workday, probably 40 of that is gross margin, 10 of that is SG&A. So let's call is about a 40 basis poin
componenttext: So yes, we had a 70 basis, in the rental business, we had a 70 basis points tailwind from energy, roughly a 40 -- when we say 40 to 50 basis points of workday, probably 40 of that is gross margin, 10 of that is SG&A. So let's call is about a 40 basis point benefit from the workday. We have talked about the energy-related customers creating a bit of a drag. Keep in mind when those customers stop or eliminate positions, that is lost revenue. But we still have the amortization of the garments, and we still are driving the truck to that customer. So we still have a lot of the costs without the revenue. That is basically an offset to that work day benefit during our first quarter. Now I will tell you also, when you compare our first quarter gross margin in the rental business to the fourth quarter, in a quarter that had the same level of energy, our gross margin was 190 basis points better. And let's take off 40 basis points from the workday, we still have a very nice sequential improvement. And we feel very, very good about that. We're getting a lot of good leverage. And the last comment I'll make is one thing to keep in mind about last year was that our first quarter gross margin in the rental was the strongest of the year. It was 50 basis points better than any other quarter. We did have a very good quarter. There was a onetime customer buyout within the quarter that helped that gross margins. And so I think we had a very good gross margin quarter. And I would expect that we're going to continue to see good leveraging within that business, knowing that we do have a little bit, we're experiencing a little bit of a tailwind, or all of the tailwind of the energy costs to go away in the latter part of the year. Does that help with that gross margin?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a perfect clarification.
componenttext: Yes. That's a perfect clarification.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Andy Whitman with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to Andy Whitman with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015

componenttext: Mike, what was the size of that buyout last year that you just mentioned? Can you quantify in terms of margins or in terms of dollars?

componenttext: Yes, we commented that it was about 50 basis points worth of growth, which would effectively mean the same kind of thing on margin.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's basically 100% flow-through when you had to do that?
componenttext: Yes, it's basically 100% flow-through when you had to do that?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on ZEE Medical I thought maybe you guys kind of call out the integration costs, closing costs, what have you, separately. But it looks like you're expensing and just running that through the P&L, and as a result, you're not showing EPS accr
componenttext: Okay. And just on ZEE Medical I thought maybe you guys kind of call out the integration costs, closing costs, what have you, separately. But it looks like you're expensing and just running that through the P&L, and as a result, you're not showing EPS accretion. But can you give us an idea of if you take out some of that onetimers and integration cost, can you give us what that would have been for the quarter as well as outlook for the year, so we can get a sense of what that normalize or introductory accretion is from ZEE?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- as you can probably tell from our guidance, we expect no impact on EPS this fiscal year. So there is -- this is a -- this acquisition is about 1/3 the size of our existing first aid business. It's a large acquisition for us, and there are a lo
componenttext: Well, we -- as you can probably tell from our guidance, we expect no impact on EPS this fiscal year. So there is -- this is a -- this acquisition is about 1/3 the size of our existing first aid business. It's a large acquisition for us, and there are a lot of integration steps to be done. We need to rebrand the trucks. We're putting into Cintas uniforms. We have to convert the systems. And we're going to be doing that over the course of the year. I would say the other thing about the the business, the routes were not as efficient as the Cintas routes. The revenue per route, the revenue per customer is not nearly as high as Cintas. And so it's -- it's a little bit more of an inefficient business, and we've got some work to do to integrate and get that to the levels where we want them to be. Having said that, the integration is going very well. And we're excited about that business and opportunity that it creates for our first aid business. I'm hesitant to get into any more specific integration costs in the first quarter. We really just got it in the month of May -- I'm sorry, in the month of August, and had a lot of meetings, training et cetera. And we're really now just getting started on that. So again I'll reiterate, in the current year, we're not expecting any accretion, but we certainly do expect to get that next fiscal year. Once we see how the integration develops of the year goes on, we'll be more in a position to provide guidance at that point.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair. We'll look forward to maybe an update on that in the next quarter. Maybe can you just give us a view, or a broad stroke view, of what you think the cost synergies of the businesses are, recognizing that there is route overlap and maybe
componenttext: Okay. That's fair. We'll look forward to maybe an update on that in the next quarter. Maybe can you just give us a view, or a broad stroke view, of what you think the cost synergies of the businesses are, recognizing that there is route overlap and maybe some route underutilization that you inherited?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not prepared to do that yet. I want to see more develop within the integration. We certainly have an integration plan, but I'd rather wait and see until we have a little bit of the integration develop.
componenttext: I'm not prepared to do that yet. I want to see more develop within the integration. We certainly have an integration plan, but I'd rather wait and see until we have a little bit of the integration develop.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fine. I guess, are you see anything different on the competitive environment in terms of pricing? You mentioned that it was additive to your quarter. It just seemed like the last 12, 18 months was, I'd say, pretty good for the overall industr
componenttext: Okay. That's fine. I guess, are you see anything different on the competitive environment in terms of pricing? You mentioned that it was additive to your quarter. It just seemed like the last 12, 18 months was, I'd say, pretty good for the overall industry. I think you guys benefited and others did too. Do you have tougher comps? Or are your competitors getting more competitive with -- for new business pricing? Is there any risk that we have to see in the future from the competitive environment?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the pricing is always competitive, there's no question about that. And we are only able to rise -- raise prices when we are showing great value to our customers. And that's the -- as long as we can continue to show that we are providing great value,
componenttext: Well, the pricing is always competitive, there's no question about that. And we are only able to rise -- raise prices when we are showing great value to our customers. And that's the -- as long as we can continue to show that we are providing great value, we don't necessarily see a change in the environment unless the economy changes. I would say that based on the pricing environment being relatively similar to last -- the last several quarters, we haven't seen a lot of competitive changes in this first quarter, but we haven't seen it yet.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And maybe just final question on the reclassification of 3 segments. I'm curious as to why the fire protection got carved out and put into the other segment, whereas the other stuff now redefines the first aid and safety business, and maybe
componenttext: Got it, okay. And maybe just final question on the reclassification of 3 segments. I'm curious as to why the fire protection got carved out and put into the other segment, whereas the other stuff now redefines the first aid and safety business, and maybe now that we have these new segments, how we should be thinking about the margins as we model forward on those.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Andy, this is Paul. You probably know the accounting guidance is pretty descriptive about operating segments, and the guidance requires that companies evaluate their segments periodically and definitely when changes occur. And we had haven't such change i
componenttext: Andy, this is Paul. You probably know the accounting guidance is pretty descriptive about operating segments, and the guidance requires that companies evaluate their segments periodically and definitely when changes occur. And we had haven't such change in our first quarter with the acquisition of ZEE. And therefore, as a result of evaluating -- reevaluating, that is, our reportable operating segments, looking at the guidance, we needed to make some changes. And the most material of those changes obviously are the fact that first aid and safety is now a stand-alone segment separate from fire. And then we also made a change in terms of including the sale of items from our catalogs to customers on our routes and including that in the Uniform Rental and Facility Services segment. So those are the 2 major changes. And then the guidance, it permits and it's acceptable then to -- once you reach a certain threshold of segments and disclosures, that the other business units then are combined into an All Other segment. And that's where fire is and that's where the direct sales business. When you're thinking about direct sale to national accounts, that type of business, that's where those reside.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, Andy, the -- that fire business, the direct sale business, they are still very important to us. We believe that they are good businesses. But we're giving visibility to 90% of our revenue going forward, and the -- and certainly, the focus is on thos
componenttext: Look, Andy, the -- that fire business, the direct sale business, they are still very important to us. We believe that they are good businesses. But we're giving visibility to 90% of our revenue going forward, and the -- and certainly, the focus is on those 2 largest businesses that we have. As it relates to the margins of that All Other, we expect improvement, just like we do in our other business. And there certainly is leverage to be gained. There are route density opportunities. And so we certainly do expect continued improvement. Because we have that direct sales business in there, it could be a little bit bumpy at times because of the ups and downs of that business. But generally speaking, we expect improvement.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. Given that direct sale now got split between 2 segments, there's a lot of moving parts. Is it -- are you guys thinking about giving us maybe last year's numbers restated for the -- on a quarterly basis for the new classification of 3 seg
componenttext: That makes sense. Given that direct sale now got split between 2 segments, there's a lot of moving parts. Is it -- are you guys thinking about giving us maybe last year's numbers restated for the -- on a quarterly basis for the new classification of 3 segments by any chance? Should we be looking for that?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually in the earnings release income statements, there is a table of supplemental information. And there, we have recasted all prior year quarters by segments. We to do gross margin, income, assets. So you'll have some good segment data under the
componenttext: Yes. Actually in the earnings release income statements, there is a table of supplemental information. And there, we have recasted all prior year quarters by segments. We to do gross margin, income, assets. So you'll have some good segment data under the new structure for fiscal '15 and then obviously, '16 going forward.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Sara with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Sara with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: Could you talk about your manufacturing clients? And are you seeing any change in their behavior?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have not seen much of a change in their behavior in this quarter compared to the last quarter. I would say that's true for not only manufacturing, but our other verticals excluding that energy-related sector.
componenttext: We have not seen much of a change in their behavior in this quarter compared to the last quarter. I would say that's true for not only manufacturing, but our other verticals excluding that energy-related sector.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then share repurchases really accelerated in the last 3 quarters. Could you talk about how we might think about share repurchase potential on a run-rate basis over time?
componenttext: Okay. And then share repurchases really accelerated in the last 3 quarters. Could you talk about how we might think about share repurchase potential on a run-rate basis over time?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I -- so as we've talked about in previous calls, our goal is to certainly to grow organically and followed by M&A. And we would love other opportunities like ZEE Medical. But when we have additional cash, we certainly will take a look at an increasing div
componenttext: I -- so as we've talked about in previous calls, our goal is to certainly to grow organically and followed by M&A. And we would love other opportunities like ZEE Medical. But when we have additional cash, we certainly will take a look at an increasing dividend. But then if there is cash remaining outside of those opportunities, our board likes to put it to work. And so I'm -- I say that, Sara, because a lot of it depends on how that cash balance looks and what the other opportunities for cash are. I would say that, that buyback program has been a -- quite a benefit, we believe, to our shareholders. And if we have available cash, we show that we'll put it to work. And I -- while I can't give you any specifics because it's a board-level decision, I would say that if we have available cash, we'd like to put it to work. We have $381 million left on our current authorization, and the board will be looking at our positions over the rest of the fiscal year.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: We'll go next to Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Guys, could you comment on specifically oil and gas customers and mining separately with regard to what inning you think you are in in add-stops on both as a headwind? It has certainly been in oil and gas. If you could just speak to both on where you thin
componenttext: Guys, could you comment on specifically oil and gas customers and mining separately with regard to what inning you think you are in in add-stops on both as a headwind? It has certainly been in oil and gas. If you could just speak to both on where you think you are in the cycle

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a tough question, Scott. I would say that it felt like from an oil rig standpoint in the first quarter, there was some stability towards the end of the quarter. But then you read an article like in today's Wall Street there are fracking firms that
componenttext: That's a tough question, Scott. I would say that it felt like from an oil rig standpoint in the first quarter, there was some stability towards the end of the quarter. But then you read an article like in today's Wall Street there are fracking firms that are starting to close up shop. It's -- that's a tough one to call. I would love to say that we're in the late innings of that oil and gas, but I don't know that I can say that. I would say that today, that as of August 31, those oil and gas customers for us, the revenue is lower today than it was at May 31 because of continued net stops. But I'm not exactly sure, Scott, where that's going to end up. From a mining perspective, we've seen some pretty hard hit. And I'm afraid I can't give you much future guidance in that either, other than to say that it's been a tough environment for the mining industries, at least for our customers. And I would expect that that's not going to turn around overnight, nor will the oil and gas customer impact turn around overnight.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And then you addressed some pricing questions earlier, but with regard to pricing across all your segments, your market, and I imagine it's kind of soft in those 2 areas you were just talking about. But it sounds like it's pretty firm elsewhere
componenttext: All right. And then you addressed some pricing questions earlier, but with regard to pricing across all your segments, your market, and I imagine it's kind of soft in those 2 areas you were just talking about. But it sounds like it's pretty firm elsewhere. Is there anywhere else outside of rental that, good or bad, that merits ? Or is everything status quo?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that everything is status quo. Now keep in mind that energy customer impact also does impact first aid and safety. We have a lot of good energy customers. But having said that, I would say that the pricing environment for most others status qu
componenttext: I would say that everything is status quo. Now keep in mind that energy customer impact also does impact first aid and safety. We have a lot of good energy customers. But having said that, I would say that the pricing environment for most others status quo.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to the Denny Galindo with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to the Denny Galindo with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on ZEE Medical. How much did the decline in margins in that first aid and safety segment was due to -- strictly due to ZEE Medical? And could we expect a similar amount of impact for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Just a quick one on ZEE Medical. How much did the decline in margins in that first aid and safety segment was due to -- strictly due to ZEE Medical? And could we expect a similar amount of impact for the rest of the year?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think -- well, we would have had a somewhat of an increase without ZEE Medical in that gross margin. I would say that if the integration continues to go well and we start the process of rebranding and putting the routes onto our systems, as the year goe
componenttext: I think -- well, we would have had a somewhat of an increase without ZEE Medical in that gross margin. I would say that if the integration continues to go well and we start the process of rebranding and putting the routes onto our systems, as the year goes on, we would expect to see some improvement. So I would expect that the drag we saw in the first quarter is going to be the worst of the year, and we should start to see a little bit of an improvement. I would say that for the year, we don't expect it necessarily to turn positive for the cumulative year. But by the fourth quarter, we could see a little bit of benefit if the integration goes well.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And another quick one there. Is there any seasonality at all to ZEE Medical? Or is there any -- I know you added 1 month this quarter. Is that a representative month? Or is it higher or lower than what should -- than what the run rat
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And another quick one there. Is there any seasonality at all to ZEE Medical? Or is there any -- I know you added 1 month this quarter. Is that a representative month? Or is it higher or lower than what should -- than what the run rate would be?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that from a seasonal standpoint, it's probably very similar to our business where we have a lot of outdoor activity in the first aid business in the summer, a lot of construction sites, et cetera. You get into the winter, you see better margin
componenttext: I would say that from a seasonal standpoint, it's probably very similar to our business where we have a lot of outdoor activity in the first aid business in the summer, a lot of construction sites, et cetera. You get into the winter, you see better margins because of the cold and flu season. So I think it would track the same kind of performance of our first aid business. Now because of the disruption that's -- that is happening because of the integration, I'm not ready to say that the month of August was representative of the year. I'd certainly love to see us improve on that, but we're going to need to let the dust clear on the integration before we can give you a quick run-rate number.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then taking a little bit of a step back, you talked a little bit about route extension. Are there any particular cities or metro areas that you're thinking could be a good opportunity? We looked at your locations, and it seemed l
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then taking a little bit of a step back, you talked a little bit about route extension. Are there any particular cities or metro areas that you're thinking could be a good opportunity? We looked at your locations, and it seemed like the big cities like New York, LA, Chicago had a very low amount of your facilities compared to the total amount. Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We think all of those areas are very good opportunities for more route density, no doubt about it. We do some comparisons internally and -- from one location to another. And we've got locations that are more mature where the route density is quite a bit h
componenttext: We think all of those areas are very good opportunities for more route density, no doubt about it. We do some comparisons internally and -- from one location to another. And we've got locations that are more mature where the route density is quite a bit higher than in some of the larger cities like New York and LA, even Philadelphia. So we think there really are some good opportunities in a lot of big cities, not just a few, but a lot. We're not nearly penetrated to the extent we think we can be.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And another cleanup one. Any update on the SAP implementation? How's that going? Are you still thinking the time line will be somewhere similar to what you thought in the past?
componenttext: Okay. And another cleanup one. Any update on the SAP implementation? How's that going? Are you still thinking the time line will be somewhere similar to what you thought in the past?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: That project is going very well. We are on the same schedule as we talked about over the last few quarters. We're on the same cost expectation as we've been over the last few quarters. And so that means that we would expect that we will come out of the re
componenttext: That project is going very well. We are on the same schedule as we talked about over the last few quarters. We're on the same cost expectation as we've been over the last few quarters. And so that means that we would expect that we will come out of the realization mode at the end, or towards the end of this fiscal year, and start to put that system to work a little bit in fiscal '17 from the standpoint of the integration -- I'm sorry, the rollout should start to happen. And so we'll see a little bit -- I should say a little bit. We'll see some cost impact, and we'll quantify that more once we yet to the point where we know we're rolling out. But we'll still see some cost impact next fiscal year.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, just a bigger picture question. One thing we've been hearing about a little bit is automation and kind of . Like our auto analyst here talks about automation in terms of self-driving cars. And you also hear a lot on the restaurant i
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, just a bigger picture question. One thing we've been hearing about a little bit is automation and kind of . Like our auto analyst here talks about automation in terms of self-driving cars. And you also hear a lot on the restaurant industry in terms of servers or various -- traditions there. Is that something that you're seeing at all in terms of your add-stops right now any impacts? Or is there something that could be a headwind in the future if some of these uniform wearers are taken out of the stock through automation?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't tell you that we could -- we've seen a noticeable impact of that. I'm sure it's happening here and there, but we haven't seen a noticeable impact. I would like to believe that we in the -- in North America are very entrepreneurial, and we're going
componenttext: I can't tell you that we could -- we've seen a noticeable impact of that. I'm sure it's happening here and there, but we haven't seen a noticeable impact. I would like to believe that we in the -- in North America are very entrepreneurial, and we're going to continue to create jobs and replace certain jobs that gets automated. And we're going to do our best to put those new jobs into uniform. We certainly believe that we want to continue to put more and different types of job functions in the uniforms, and we're going to continue to work on that. I think we've been very successful over the last handful of years, and we're going to continue to look for those opportunities. And I like to bet on the North American entrepreneur to create more jobs, and we're going to put them in uniform.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Gary Bisbee with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could share with us just to help us think about the trending, what the organic revenue growth was for the new segments over the 4 quarters of last year?
componenttext: I wondered if you could share with us just to help us think about the trending, what the organic revenue growth was for the new segments over the 4 quarters of last year?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: I believe that I can give you a little bit of that, yes. So let me talk Uniform Rental and Facility Services. In the first quarter last year, it was 8.5%. In the second quarter, it was 8.1%. In the third quarter, it was 7.9%. And as Paul mentioned, in the
componenttext: I believe that I can give you a little bit of that, yes. So let me talk Uniform Rental and Facility Services. In the first quarter last year, it was 8.5%. In the second quarter, it was 8.1%. In the third quarter, it was 7.9%. And as Paul mentioned, in the fourth quarter, it was 6.2%. So not a whole lot different from what we reported, especially directionally. From a first aid and safety standpoint, 10% even in the first quarter, 13.7% in the second quarter, 10.6% in the third quarter, 8.2% in the fourth quarter. From an All Other standpoint, it was 0.8% in the first quarter. It was negative 0.5% in the second quarter, 3.6% in the third quarter, 3.8% in the fourth quarter. And you can kind of see there a little bit of bumpiness that we talked about in that direct sale business.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015

componenttextpreview: I would say that -- so you can think about the -- let's look at the midpoint of the range of Paul gave of $575 million in proceeds. Now one thing to keep in mind is some of those proceeds will drag out a little bit with kind of a customary holdbacks, but
componenttext: I would say that -- so you can think about the -- let's look at the midpoint of the range of Paul gave of $575 million in proceeds. Now one thing to keep in mind is some of those proceeds will drag out a little bit with kind of a customary holdbacks, but let's go to the midpoint of that number. You will see on the balance sheet that there is a -- an asset held for sale of $194.275 million. That is our book value. The difference between the proceeds and that book value is a gain on which we'll have tax of 37.3%. In addition to that, on the balance sheet, there's liability held for sale of $78.457 million. And that essentially is a deferred tax item because we did not pay any tax on last year's gain at the time of the transaction, nor did we pay tax on the dividend that occurred in May. So that when we pay taxes, we'll have a little bit of a catch-up because of that deferred liability. I would expect that as Paul said, we'll see -- we expect that to close in the fourth quarter of this calendar year. I would expect that if that happens, we'll pay those taxes in the first calendar quarter of next year.

componenttext: Well, yes. It's built into our tax rate. And so you'll see essentially a net income that is the after-tax gain.

componenttext: That's fine. Don't worry about it. one bigger picture question. I think you've been asked this in a different way earlier. But fiscal '15 was the second year in a row where you pushed out plant capacity additions that you'd talked about at the beginning of the year. And I guess, I just wanted to understand, once or twice, commented that permitting and things like that was part of the issue. But how is utilization across the entire network? And do you have markets today that aren't growing because you're so short on capacity? Or was that really -- as the additions that you've talked about and delayed, is that more sort of giving you the capacity to grow for several more years?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- there certainly are those logistical issues of finding the right land, getting the permitting done and then actually building the building. We have -- we certainly do have some markets that have capacity that's getting typed. It's not preventin
componenttext: Yes, we -- there certainly are those logistical issues of finding the right land, getting the permitting done and then actually building the building. We have -- we certainly do have some markets that have capacity that's getting typed. It's not preventing us from growing, but we're getting close in some of those markets. And we do need to add some capacity, and our expectation is that we'll do that towards the back end of this year, but it not prevented us from growing.

componenttext: John, I honestly I don't have that at my fingertips. And I don't think I'd like to give that level of detail for competitive reasons. headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes I -- we talked a lot last year about that oil and gas being 2% to 3% of our total revenue. That sector has gotten hit pretty hard. I would say that while that -- the sector has been hit hard and maybe a little bit harder than we expected, we haven't s
componenttext: Yes I -- we talked a lot last year about that oil and gas being 2% to 3% of our total revenue. That sector has gotten hit pretty hard. I would say that while that -- the sector has been hit hard and maybe a little bit harder than we expected, we haven't seen the spillover to be that much more significant and really not any more significant than what we would expect throughout the course of the last year. I think it's -- it has been fairly connected to that energy sector. But we've been able to grow quite well despite that, and so we don't see a lot of spillover.

componenttext: Okay. And then I wanted to ask on the M&A front. Clearly, you're after organic growth. That's your biggest priority. I think we're all pretty familiar with what's available to you in terms of asset potential on the uniform side, but can you talk a little bit more about the first aid and safety? componenttext: There are some small independent opportunities that could be out there. ZEE did have a franchise network, and so there's some opportunities there at the right value. I would say there are not a lot of other large players. When we think about that business, the competition is coming from the smaller players, but also the do-it-yourselfers, the Grangers, the people going down to Walmart or Sam's Club. So I would say that the M&A as the business exists today is likely going to be smaller tuck-in opportunities.

componenttext: Well, the annual revenues, as we mentioned in our press release, are about -- we would expect $110 million to $120 million. componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Cintas Quarterly Earnings Results Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. Mike Hansen, Vice President of Finance and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining us tonight. With me is Paul Adler, Cintas' Vice President and Treasurer. We will discuss our first quarter results for fiscal 2016. After our commentary, we will be happy to answer questions.The Private Securities
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining us tonight. With me is Paul Adler, Cintas' Vice President and Treasurer. We will discuss our first quarter results for fiscal 2016. After our commentary, we will be happy to answer questions.
The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 provides a safe harbor from civil litigation for forward-looking statements. This conference call contains forward-looking statements that reflect the company's current views as to future events and financial performance. These forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, which could cause actual results to differ materially from those we may discuss. I refer you to the discussion on these points contained in our most recent filings with the SEC.
As we reported today in the press release, please note that a change in our reportable segments. U.S. generally accepted accounting principles require companies to evaluate their reportable operating segments when certain events occur.
As a result of a recent evaluation, effective June 1, 2015, we will report the following operating segments: Uniform Rental and Facility Services, First Aid and Safety Services and All Other. All Other primarily consists of Fire Protection Services and our Direct Sale business division.
We are pleased to report first quarter revenue of $1,199,000,000, an increase of 8.8% from the prior year first quarter. Organic revenue growth, which adjusts for the impact of acquisitions, workday differences and foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, was 6.8%. Organic revenue growth for our Uniform Rental and Facility Services segment was 6.8%, and the First Aid and Safety Services segment organic growth was 10.5%. The performance of our sales force in both segments was strong. We continue to add new customers and provide existing customers with additional products and services from our broad line.
First quarter operating income was $185.5 million, which was 15.5% of revenue compared to an operating margin of 14.8% in the prior year period. This represents a 70-basis-point improvement from last year's operating margin.
Net income from continuing operations for the first quarter of fiscal year 2016 was $106.2 million, and earnings per diluted share or EPS from continuing operations for the first quarter were $0.93. Note that the first quarter of last year's -- of last fiscal year's net income and EPS from continuing operations were positively impacted by a gain from the sale of stock in an equity method investment. Excluding this gain, first quarter net income and EPS from continuing operations increased 15.1% and 19.2%, respectively, compared to the prior year.  Net income from continuing operations as a percent of revenue improved 50 basis points to 8.9% from 8.4% of revenue in last fiscal year's first quarter, excluding the prior year period gain.
We also demonstrated our continuing commitment to providing shareholder value through our stock buyback program. During August and into September through the close of business yesterday, Cintas purchased 2.9 million shares of common stock. This share buyback had no impact on first quarter EPS, but is expected to benefit full fiscal year EPS by $0.05. Since the beginning of fiscal 2016, approximately 4.5 million shares of common stock have been purchased at an aggregate cost of $381.2 million. As of September 23, 2015, Cintas had $381.8 million available under the current Board of Directors stock repurchase authorization.
As Cintas CEO Scott Farmer stated in today's press release, we are off to a good start to our fiscal 2016 year. We thank our employees, whom we call partners, for their strong performance.
On August 1, 2015, the company closed on the acquisition of ZEE Medical for a consideration of approximately $134 million in cash. About $121 million were paid at the closing of the transaction and an additional $13 million may be paid in future fiscal years subject to holdback provisions. We are in the very early stages of the integration of the ZEE business. We are excited about the benefits and opportunities this acquisition provides, including expanding our footprint and enabling us to serve an even greater number of customers in North America.
As a result of our first quarter results and the recent acquisition of ZEE Medical, we are updating our annual guidance. We expect fiscal 2016 revenue to be in the range of $4,800,000,000 to $4,880,000,000 and fiscal 2016 EPS from continuing operations to be in the range of $3.79 to $3.88. This guidance does not include any EPS impact from the announced agreement to sell our investment in Shred-it, which has not yet closed. This guidance does not include any potential deterioration in the U.S. economy or additional share buybacks. The EPS guidance is detailed in a table within today's press release.
I'll now turn the call over to Paul for more details on company financial performance.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. First, please note that there were 66 workdays in this year's first quarter compared to 65 in last year's first quarter. The second and third quarters of this fiscal year will have the same number of workdays as last year of 65. This year's
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. First, please note that there were 66 workdays in this year's first quarter compared to 65 in last year's first quarter. The second and third quarters of this fiscal year will have the same number of workdays as last year of 65. This year's fourth quarter will have 66 workdays compared to 65 in last year's fourth quarter. Thus, fiscal year 2016 will have 262 workdays, 2 more than in fiscal 2015.
As Mike stated, total revenue increased organically by 6.8% in the first quarter. New business wins, penetration of existing customers with more products and services, retention and price increases, also -- all contributed to the strong growth rate. Total company gross margin was 43.7% for the first quarter of this year compared to 43.4% last year. Total company energy-related expenses for this year's first quarter were 2.2%. Last year's first quarter energy-related expenses were 2.8%.
As Mike previously stated, effective June 1, 2015, we have 3 reportable operating segments: Uniform Rental and Facility Services, First Aid and Safety Services and All Other. All Other consists primarily of Fire Protection Services and our Direct Sale business division. First Aid and Safety Services and All Other are combined and presented as Other Services on the income statement.
The Uniform Rental and Facility Services operating segment includes the rental and servicing of uniforms, mats and towels and the provision of restroom supplies and other facility products and services. The segment also includes the sale of items from our catalogs to our customers on route.
Uniform Rental and Facility Services revenue was $938 million, an increase of 7.4% compared to last year's first quarter. Organic growth, which excludes the impact of acquisitions, workday differences and foreign currency exchange rate changes, was 6.8%. For comparative purposes, this segment's organic growth for the previous quarter, our fiscal 2015 fourth quarter, was 6.2%. Our Uniform Rental and Facility Services segment gross margin was 44.7% for the first quarter, an increase of 90 basis points from 43.8% in last year's first quarter. Energy-related costs were 70 basis points lower than in last year's first quarter.
Our First Aid and Safety Services operating segment includes revenue from the sale and servicing of first aid products, safety products and training. This segment's revenue for the first quarter was $99 million, which was 24.5% higher than last year's first quarter. Total growth benefited from the ZEE Medical acquisition. On an organic basis, growth was 10.5%. This was a good sequential increase in the growth rate from 8.2% in our fourth quarter. This segment's gross margin was 42.3% in the first quarter compared to 45.9% in the prior year period. Energy-related costs were 40 basis points lower than in last year's first quarter.
As Mike stated earlier, we are in the very beginning stages of the integration of the ZEE business. As expected, our First Aid and Safety Services results were negatively impacted by conversion costs, the amortization of intangible assets resulting from the purchase price accounting and other charges. This impact will continue in the short term as we assimilate the acquired business and begin to realize the synergies. We are excited about the benefits and opportunities that this acquisition provides.
Regarding selling and general and administrative expenses. Total company SG&A was 28.2% as a percentage of first quarter revenue compared to a total company SG&A in last year's first quarter of 28.5%. The 30-basis-point improvement in SG&A was realized despite a 40 basis point increase in medical expenses this quarter compared to last year.
On July 15, 2015, Cintas announced that it entered into a definitive agreement to sell its investment in Shred-it for approximately $550 million to $600 million before taxes. The transaction is still expected to close in the fourth quarter of calendar year 2015. As a result of the announced sale of the investment, the related income or loss is now reported in discontinued operations. The investment in Shred-it on the balance sheet is recorded as assets held for sale and a related tax liability is recorded as liabilities held for sale.
Our effective tax rate for the first quarter was 37.2%, the same rate as in the prior year period. We expect the full year 2016 effective tax rate to be 37.3%.
Our cash and marketable securities were $200 million at August 31, a decrease of $233 million from the $433 million on May 31. Cash provided by operating activities was $143 million in our first quarter. Uses of cash included $121 million net of cash acquired were acquisitions and about $222 million were repurchases of Cintas common stock.
Capital expenditures for the first quarter were approximately $63 million. Our CapEx by reportable operating segment was as follows: $55 million in Uniform Rental, $4 million in First Aid and Safety and $4 million in All Other. We expect CapEx for fiscal 2016 to be in the range of $250 million to $300 million.
That concludes our prepared remarks. We are happy to answer your questions.

componenttext: This is actually Greg calling on for Manav. Just wanted to ask about the guidance. componenttext: You're correct. Without ZEE and without the share buyback impact, the guidance is generally the same. Our first quarter results were generally in line, and we still feel good about the year. There's no change in the way that we feel about that, with maybe the only possible exception of the Canadian dollar continues to weaken. Today, it was somewhere in the CAD 1.33, CAD 1.34 range, which is a little bit weaker than we guided at CAD 1.25. So we may see a little bit of top line impact as we go through the rest of the year. But aside from that, we still feel good about the year and not really any change to our thinking.

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015

componenttext: Fair enough. And then on the M&A environment, should we think of ZEE Medical as kind of a one-off opportunity that you've had or are you seeing comparatively larger companies coming available recently?

headline: Cintas Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 24, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, ZEE is a great opportunity for us and one that we feel very excited about. It certainly does demonstrate that we want to put our cash to work. And we really do like the opportunities for M&A, particularly in a case like ZEE where there's
componenttext: Well, certainly, ZEE is a great opportunity for us and one that we feel very excited about. It certainly does demonstrate that we want to put our cash to work. And we really do like the opportunities for M&A, particularly in a case like ZEE where there's a lot of tuck-in opportunity. I would say, I can't comment on any other items because I wouldn't want to speculate, but we're certainly continuing to be active and looking for opportunities to add value through M&A.

componenttext: Well, we -- a number of things. As Paul mentioned, we had a very good new business quarter. One of the things in the last call that we talked about was a little bit of preparing in the fourth quarter to get off to a good start. So we hired -- we probably hired some reps early. We added some routes earlier. And we got some good momentum going into the year, and that continued through the quarter. New business was very strong. Penetration -- I'm sorry, customer retention was a little bit better than last year, so another benefit, not as significant as the new business. Pricing was, I would say, the environment didn't change much, but it was still a fairly positive environment with the exception of our energy-related customers. So those 3 areas all contributed. I will say that there was a little bit of an offset from those energy-related customers as we've talked the last several quarters. Our oil and gas customers are certainly operating under difficult environments as well as our mining customers. And we saw our uniform rental net add-stops being negative for the quarter, so there was a bit of a drag from that, but certainly...
